comment_text:
This is the first video in a series about the US Coast Guard. Here in the US we just kind of know that the Coast Guard always has our back, but we don't really think about how they do what they do. I wanted to get a better understanding for what goes into saving lives, so I'm excited to share this, the first video in a whole series on the Coast Guard. So far I've filmed in Mobile AL, Destin FL, and New Orleans LA. Imagine waking up every day and figuring out how to save people. Incredibly awesome. I hope you will consider subscribing to Smarter Every Day for the upcoming videos in this series. I believe you will find them to be fascinating.

Also, I would like express my heartfelt gratitude for every Thinker and Doer that supports Smarter Every Day on Patreon at https://www.patreon.com/smartereveryday . Seriously, I cannot say enough kind things about all of you. All of you, of course, except Joseph Robinson. In the last video Joseph requested that I shoot a supersonic baseball at a gallon of mayo, and I still haven't quite forgiven him. (I jest, but seriously THANK YOU Patrons)



Warm Regards,


Destin

This brought me back to one of my meteorology classes at UAH last spring. It was based on what's called DSS, or decision support services. We had exercises where we acted as a National Weather Service office and one of the things we did was send information to partners. One of those times was a Coast Guard representative (an actual person working in the Coast Guard) and we would provide weather information for specific locations. Not sure if it'll come up later on in this series, but we would give information for wind speed and direction, wave heights, water temperatures, and other pertinent information (those are just the ones I remember). It's really cool to see things on their side.

It starts with me contacting the Coast Guard and four hours later my heart attack patient finally gets picked up. The flight time from the base to the location of the heart attack victim is 46 minutes. The amount of bureaucracy and BS these heroes have to go through is astonishing. Four instance, because we were no longer on a boat and had gotten to a beach (for the comfort of the man having the heart attack) the Coast Guard had to get permission/hand off from the state patrol before they could scramble.

Wilson Lock, Wheeler Lock, Guntersville Lock and further up you have Nickajack Lock. I'm sure you know of them. And the ports at Decatur, Guntersville and even the history of Red Stone Arsenal's river usage are quit interesting. Again, thank youl

I was a coast guardsman from 1973 to 1977 right at the tail end of the Vietnam war. It is without a doubt the best thing to ever happen to me because it took me to places and experiences that I would never had if not for the guard. For example: My first duty station out of basic training was a LORAN station in central Thailand. There were 20 of us on this tiny unit situated on the Royal Thai Airforce Base Udorn Thani. WOW! My next was school at the Petaluma training center, then the buoy tender Iris in Astoria Oregon, then the LORAN Station Geisashi Japan, then the LORAN Station Iwo Jima (TAD 3 months and 2 days), and finally the SAR Station at Grand Isle Louisiana. It was like being in the boy scouts, one adventure after another, after another.

Got news for you, the group I'm a member of is under the DHS and FEMA as well. I'm allowed to go out in winds of up to 50 Mph, not that I would, but our charter says I can. I'm a retired CWO3 Navy but I work with CERT {Community Emergency Response Team). We follow up on hurricanes and tornados looking for and marking those things that we have turned off for safety [water, gas, and electric] and mark the front of the structure letting others who might be looking in the same area that this building has been checked and what damages if any were found, including those who are injured. We triage those injured and depending on how badly they are injured we can escalate all the way to sending them to a hospital. I'm a ham operator, so I have better communication with the EOC than some others have. I was qualified to work under CERT back in 2002 and recertified to meet the newer criteria for rescuing people in 2017. The area I live in has Eglin and Hurlburt AFB's, an Army Ranger Camp, a naval EOD training field on Eglin, and in Destin, FL the US Coast Guard station just outside of the Destin harbor.
I was a scoutmaster for 7 years and know the woods of the Eglin facility rather well. While I retired from work back in 2017, I'm still active.

When I worked for the park service out on Alcatraz, we had plenty of contact with the Coast Guard, for a couple reasons. Mainly, the lighthouse is still an active "aid to navigation", and is maintained by the CG. They also help and have regulatory authority over things like the ferries that bring people out to the island, as well as, if any of our tanks were to leak. We have fuel tanks for the generators, batteries for the solar system, water for drinking, sewage from the toilets, etc. Not very good if any of that leaked.

We actually had a ship on patrol out of Eureka, the USCGC Barracuda, pull up and pretty much ask "hey, can we have a tour?" "Ya, sure, come ashore!" A couple of us got tours of the ship, too. It was quite impressive, from the bridge, to the kitchen, the engine room, the sleeping quarters... Great running boat. I was also able to get a tour at Sector Golden Gate, right under the Golden Gate Bridge in Sausalito. Great people, great facility, AMAZING views. But, definitely high stress. They handle things like recovery of jumpers off the bridge. One of the guys I talked to had to do that his first day on duty. That why that particular surf station has the highest turn-over rate out of all the stations in the country (at least a few years ago).

Great group of folks. I'm glad they're around, and they're fun being around, both giving tours of their ships and stations, and taking tours of old prisons.

Destin, I respect you a lot, but I have to tell you and anyone else:
If you ever find your self in some kind of operation center, and there is an incoming call, PLEASE don't stick your microphone and camera in the face of the person who answers. This are critical seconds, and you don't want to distract or disturb this person. In such moments, if you don't have any assigned role - just be 'a fly on the wall'. Don't let anyone who's busy to even notice that you are there.
It's maybe sounds like I'm too dramatic, but as long as you are not part of the operations, especially when the first call could be anything from a small event to a major one - you can not really know if and how much your actions, or even presence, is distracting.
Don't worry about losing "exciting video" or something like that. You, Destin, are bigger than that, and your followers too will appreciate more knowing that you doing the responsible thing, even if it means less to non cool videos.
I know that you are a responsible person, and that nothing awful didn't happen here, but I'm speaking from my heart and my long time experience in operation centers. Your instinct, your first reaction, should be 'I don't want to bother anyone here', and not 'Wow, I get to record a live action'. Don't be a journalist. They are immoral scavengers.
Much appreciation for you and your work.

This old Hooligan Sailor served on two small boat stations and a famous cutter, the Tamaroa, did over 400 search and rescue cases, maybe 500, and the rescue center call in the video was real and the reaction was too. It's a sweet thing to be able to pull off a rescue, and I don't know about anyone else but I for one felt clean and calm days after, everytime. I'd highly recommend a visit to a rough weather surf station on a nasty gray overcast day with a hard blowing wind and riding a USCG MotorLifeboat out there in some breaking bar surf for some real fun. Don't mind that doctors want to fuse discs in by back and replace a knee because of those rescues, I tell you if I could do it again, I'd say yes everday of the week and twice on Sunday, it was a blast. Shame on the Navy too, they really should have taught you what a chart is, really, and that's exactly why the USCG is around, someone has to keep this salty nautical sailor stuff alive and kicking! Looks like a great series.  I was a Coastie from '69 - '73.  Very formative years for me, right out of high school.  Still have many friends from my service days.  Started as a deckhand on a buoy-tender in LA harbor, went to Avionics school in Elizabeth City, NC.  Served at USCG Air stations in Port Angeles, WA and Los Angeles, CA. Repaired aircraft navigation and communications electronics in the Avionics shop, and flew as radio operator / navigator  on Grumman Albatross seaplanes on many search and rescue cases along the WA and OR coastlines.  In our day there was no Homeland Security Department.  The CG was a part of the Dept of Transportation.  Have always been proud of my CG service and look forward to your upcoming episodes.  Thanks.

Hi Destin, I'm a sailor myself and a long Patreon of your awesome channel. Writing to you from Germany, I was wondering if there is a legal necessity for bigger yachts or charter yachts to have a VHF-radio on board and the duty to hold a valid SRC (short range certificate for radio) in the US. I recently started a training to get my own SRC and I was amazed by the international standards the regulate not only the use of specific frequencies, but also the language codes for emergency messages and the organisation of SAR operations. I hope you have intended to shed a light on that in your series. If not, I can only recommend you to creata an "add-on video", as everthing from radio messages over EPIRBs and SARSAT has some outstanding ingenuity in terms of communication and information organisation at its core, that fascinated me when first encountering that field.

Empathy is relatively new word that is often confused as sympathy++. Seems like a small issue, I know, but it's being used interchangeably in some important texts and scenarios lately. By showing sympathy, she conveys understanding of the callers' emotions or situation. Empathy, is closer to putting herself in the same emotional state as the caller, which would not be helpful.

Back in the early 90s, I worked in the Defense Information Systems Agency in the basement of The Pentagon, and our branch supported the Logistics Directorate of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. I certainly saw my share of Coast Guard types while I was there, and the five walls of the building did represent the US Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, and Coast Guard.

The Logistics Directorate had a Logistics Readiness Center that would get activated for operations needing logistical support, including the invasion of Panama to capture Manuel Noriega, as well as Desert Shield/Desert Storm.

What I recall of the LRC for Action Officers isn’t much different from what you saw, just that their computer monitors in 1990 were a lot smaller and not so flat. And I don’t think whiteboards had been invented yet. But most everything else looked very similar. Of course, they had desks for a dozen Action Officers, all of whom were Lt.Col. rank or higher (or equivalent grades in the Navy). So, the room was a bit bigger. And the Team Chief had his own office, which was locked separately from the rest of the space.

Back in the back, we Analyst/Terminal Operators were running on much older equipment connected to classified military mainframes that were built in the 60s. We started off with green screen text-based terminals, which were later replaced by IBM PC/XT systems with removable 5MB hard drives. We also had line printers. We didn’t have any of the newer fancier stuff, but then we didn’t need it in order to do our jobs.

My grandfather has been lost in history sadly, and he was in the Coast Guard during WW2.
I have a picture of 1 of the ships he was on, the US cutter Taney.
He was stationed in Juneau Alaska, San Francisco Bay, and St. Louis, which I've 2 papers from San Fran. He was sent a note to let him know of the birth of my mother, and I've the note he sent back of congrats and well being for my grandmother and my mother.
I've 2 of his.... mugs I guess you'd call them. One is made of metal with a glass bottom and the other ceramic, they show 2 different ships.
The last place he was stationed at was in St. Louis.
This is sadly where his papers all went missing and after searching they assume that his papers must've been destroyed from a fire that happened there.
So, the 2 papers I have and anything my aunt or cousin have, is all that remains.
His ashes are with a brother of mine, and I remember part of my grandfathers will that was read in front of me, is that he wanted them spread over Mt McKinley in Alaska.
We're still hoping to fulfill my grandfathers last wish that was in his Will, which I had tried to see if the coast guard could make that happen for us. Sadly no.
My brother, still has the ashes, last I know of.

I spent 9 years as an Aux, finally becoming a Division Captain . . . we did a lot of good and saved more than a few lives on the Tennessee River.

We notified USCG about our situation and that we might drift into a shipping channel. We had passsengers that were incapacitated from motion sickness. The cutter arrived, boarded our boat, insisted that our captain leave the helm to show them our safety gear (horn, flares, radio, etc.), then left us there to wait for a marine tow company. They didn't help us get away from the traffic lane, nor stabilize our position, nor aid our sick folks. They just took the captain away from the helm long enough to inspect our boat. I get it that no one was likely about to die, but if they were going to help, then help. If they weren't going to help, then don't take the risk of boarding a boat in rough seas just to distract the captain. Lacked some common sense, IMO.

In the 1980s while taking a client of my father's out on our racing sloop for an evening sail on Lake Huron (we both were very experienced sailors), in a freak situation, the boat capsized. Normally, the boat would self-right; unfortunately the dry hatches blew open and the entire boat filled with water. There was no way to right the boat. We always wore life jackets thankfully. We were three hours overdue and it is now past 23:00 hours. Fortunately the Coast Guard found us, with another boat showing up moments later. Even in the summer, the Great Lakes can be cold; three hours in the water, OMG. So grateful for the USCG!

This made me remember a story. Long ago I bought some binoculars for looking at the sky at night. One day my parents asked to borrow them since they were going on a trip to a mountain that had a good view of the sea. I couldn’t accompany them since I had work that day. During the night that day I received a call from my parents asking me if I knew the phone number for the Coast Guard. I looked for it and gave it to them and asked what was going on. They told me they’ve seen a light in the sea and when they looked with the binoculars it was a fishing boat that caught on fire. After that they told me they saw the coast guard arrive to the boat. I say this every time a CG video crosses my feed, and I'm gonna say it again.
I'm an Army veteran, a proud old cavalry corporal, but I have a lot of respect for the USCG
There are towns on the coastal US [East, West, Gulf, Lakes, Alaska, Hawai'i, and the Mississippi ] where every single person knows somebody pulled out of the drink by Coasties. And for all you hoo-ah veteran types who insist on calling them 'puddle pirates' I got two things for you:
1] The Coast Guard goes out on rescues in weather that'd make Santa Claus stay home. There's an old Coastie bo'sun's saying: 'You gotta go out, but you don't always get to come back'.
2] In the military our jobs are relatively simple. National Command Authority pulls the trigger and we put our training into execution. The CG's life is way more complicated. They have combat roles, of course, but also law enforcement, maritime regulatory, maintenance of seaways, and first responder duties. Putting it as simply as I can, the military's job is dealing with the enemies of our nation; the CG's job is dealing with Mother Nature and Human Stupidity... their best day on the job is just breaking even!

How a corporation that produces video-based content hasn't thrown all the money at you yet to make your own series for them, is baffling to me. I don't know what you have going on behind the scenes and what kind of contract you'd need to be offered to give up the autonomy you have now, but, come on. A long form (30 minute to an hour) show with you just exploring the things that interested you and/or a team of producers that month would be fantastic.

Basically, taking SED and making it bigger with more budget. Though, thinking about it, that might undermine the intimacy and personal aspect of the content. Which is what makes it so much more endearing than something on, say, The History Channel, or Netflix. The way you get excited and drill down into the subject until you feel satisfied, stop being interested, or hit the wall of "No one knows" is very much a part of the charm.

So maybe a show with five cameras, 3 different people interviewing the subjects from different departments, a group of writers, a director, a corporate overlord you have to appease, and all the other bureaucracy is just muddying a good thing for no reason. Just having a second person interact with the people in this video would sever a huge chunk of what makes it so enjoyable. Since they aren't excitedly asking questions and making sure they understood what was conveyed to them, asking follow-up questions that show an understanding for what was explained and that helps shed light on the subject, and the other little things that only "Destin" does. So, I think I answered my own question...

I just am surprised you've not had that offer yet, if that is, in fact, the case.

Listening to LtJG Smith describe her role and what goes into doing what she does every day is pretty much the exact same thing that us 911 operators/call takers/ emergency service dispatchers also do. We must remain calm because if we don't, we can't get all the information we need for our responders to do their jobs. It all starts with us and that's no different here. It all starts with her and those who do her job. The more we can connect with that caller, the more trust that caller will have in us and the more and better information we can obtain from them to help with their situation. If you ever have to call 911 or the USCG or any emergency agency, please understand that there is a reason why we ask the questions we ask. It all paints a picture that allows us to better serve you, the caller.

I was in the Norwegian coast guard for about 1 year and i was stationed in one of the "Ytre Kystvakt" vessels which means outer coastguard (outer part of the ocean, and not close to land) . Its very similar to this video. We get information about vessels, trawlers, people almost dying because of accidents etc. So if we are one of the closest vessels, we do that mission and help as much as we can.
Its a very fun job, but can be very demanding depending on what we are doing.
A lot of practice with MOB and using the "sjøbjørn" which means seabear. Its the orange RIB we are using in all different weathers and conditions.

It would be very cool if you managed to visit one of the coastguard boats, especially the ones made in 2009 (newest vessels). The vessel i was in is called "KV Barentshav".
We had civils onboard that was there for a visit over a 1-2 weeks period. So it might be possible for you as well :)

While on paper, the coast guard is four years older than the US navy, it's not really true.
The only reason it's older is because after the revolutionary war, the newly formed and loosely banded states did not want to and could not afford to have a navy. Instead opting to focus on internal matters. Land based matters so to speak.
In short, the continental navy predated the "coast guard" by 15 years. And it was only because they disbanded the continental navy after the war that the Revenue Cutter Service, technically on paper, is four years older than the US navy.

Adding to that, saying things like "x is older than y" really depends on how far back you wanna go... I'd bet you whatever boat hit the water first in a line of successions (I.E, early England who then sailed to the Americas) and then the Royal Navy or whatever really was the origin of what we know today as the coast guard. Because that's where everyone originated from.

... Or we can just say it all started about 4.5 billion years ago.

In those days, they would roll the boat in rough surf. If you were able to hold on until it rolled back upright, you passed. I understand they don’t roll the boats anymore for training.

Thank you for shining a light on these brave women and men. People don’t usually realize everything the Coast Guard does.

Another interesting angle is that USCG has to do law enforcement activities such as drunk boaters, drug interdiction with live weapon fire, safety checks, and environmental protection etc can all be confronted within USCG duties. And these can be done without the same protections and limitations as normal law enforcement. Normal law enforcement need probable cause, reasonable suspicion, plain sight evidence, and warrants to do searches or to stop someone. Legally, the USCG needs none of that for a stop, board, and inspect a vessel underway. Furthermore, the CG gets to write its own regulations on what is enforced.

And yet, as far as I know, the USCG has a really good relationship with recreational boaters in general, works well with industry, and tries to find a good balance between safety, environment, and economic needs. Their sailors have a good reputation of being respectful and disciplined.
